headline.main: Animal Welfare Advocates Notch a Win Against Dog Traders

docs.abstract: A group of animal lovers from across China rescued about 2,400 dogs that might have otherwise ended up on the dinner table.
docs.snippet: A group of animal lovers from across China rescued about 2,400 dogs that might have otherwise ended up on the dinner table.

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. government will not renew funding for a major research project into Lassa fever, a decision that will, in turn, cut resources for a facility in Sierra Leone that is at the forefront of the current battle against the Ebola virus.

headline.main: Exclusive: U.S. Cuts Resources for Project Involved in Ebola Battle in Sierra Leone
headline.print_headline: Exclusive: U.S. Cuts Resources for Project Involved in Ebola Battle in Sierra Leone

docs.snippet: The U.S. government will not renew funding for a major research project into Lassa fever, a decision that will, in turn, cut resources for a facility in Sierra Leone that is at the forefront of the current battle against the Ebola virus.

docs.abstract: A series of problematic choices confront anyone dealing with cancer.
docs.snippet: A series of problematic choices confront anyone dealing with cancer.

docs.lead_paragraph: The army blockaded on Thursday rural areas in Sierra Leone that have been hit by the deadly Ebola virus, a senior officer said, after neighboring Liberia declared a state of emergency to tackle the worst outbreak of the disease on record.

headline.main: Sierra Leone Army Blockades Ebola Areas, Liberia Declares Emergency
headline.print_headline: Sierra Leone Army Blockades Ebola Areas, Liberia Declares Emergency

docs.snippet: The army blockaded on Thursday rural areas in Sierra Leone that have been hit by the deadly Ebola virus, a senior officer said, after neighboring Liberia declared a state of emergency to tackle the worst outbreak of the disease on record.

headline.main: Think Like a Doctor: Losing It

docs.abstract: A former state trooper begins wasting away, losing body hair and falling down. Can you solve a medical mystery that stumped the man’s doctors?
docs.snippet: A former state trooper begins wasting away, losing body hair and falling down. Can you solve a medical mystery that stumped the man’s doctors?

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. Steinfeld, the surgeon general in Nixon’s first term, brought new attention to the risks cigarettes posed to women and to people exposed to secondhand smoke.

headline.main: Jesse L. Steinfeld, Surgeon General and Tobacco Foe, Dies at 87
headline.print_headline: Jesse L. Steinfeld, 87, Surgeon General and Tobacco Foe, Dies

docs.abstract: Jessie L Steinfeld, who as surgeon general in the Nixon administration spoke out against cigarette smoking, bringing attention to risks cigarettes pose to women and to people exposed to secondhand smoke, dies at age 87.
docs.snippet: Mr. Steinfeld, the surgeon general in Nixon’s first term, brought new attention to the risks cigarettes posed to women and to people exposed to secondhand smoke.

docs.lead_paragraph: An experimental medicine that has been called a “secret serum” is being given to two Americans infected with Ebola.

headline.main: Ebola Therapy From an Obscure Biotech Firm Is Hurried Along
headline.print_headline: An Obscure Biotech Firm Hurries Ebola Treatment

docs.abstract: San Diego-based Mapp Biopharmaceuticals is focused on how to manufacture more of so-called secret serum ZMapp, which is being used for the first time to treat American patients infected with Ebola virus; World Health Organization has said it will convene panel of medical ethicists to explore use of experimental treatment in outbreak in West Africa.
docs.snippet: An experimental medicine that has been called a “secret serum” is being given to two Americans infected with Ebola.

headline.main: Bush Urges Renewed Fight Against Deadly Diseases in Africa

keywords.value: President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief

docs.lead_paragraph: The use of an experimental drug to treat two Americans diagnosed with Ebola is raising ethical questions about who gets first access to unproven new therapies for the deadly disease. But some health experts fear debate over extremely limited doses will distract from tried-and-true measures to curb the growing outbreak — things like more rapidly identifying and isolating the sick.

headline.main: Ethical Issue: Who Gets Experimental Ebola Drug?
headline.print_headline: Ethical Issue: Who Gets Experimental Ebola Drug?

docs.snippet: The use of an experimental drug to treat two Americans diagnosed with Ebola is raising ethical questions about who gets first access to unproven new therapies for the deadly disease. But some health experts fear debate over extremely limited doses...

docs.lead_paragraph: The use of an experimental drug on two U.S. charity workers with the deadly Ebola virus has prompted the World Health Organization (WHO) to consider the implications of making such treatments more widely available, it said on Wednesday.

headline.main: WHO Consults Ethics Experts on Wider Use of Experimental Ebola Drugs
headline.print_headline: WHO Consults Ethics Experts on Wider Use of Experimental Ebola Drugs

docs.snippet: The use of an experimental drug on two U.S. charity workers with the deadly Ebola virus has prompted the World Health Organization (WHO) to consider the implications of making such treatments more widely available, it said on Wednesday.
